text: <@U1KGSF37C|budiwiyono> has joined the channel
<@U1KF3LG59|amerkez> has joined the channel
Is there a limit of block size in Hyperledger? We know that is 1MB in Bitcoin. Thanks

I'm also curious about size limitation. I'd like to see the wiki page for possible limitations to understand the architecture better.    As for the size of block, it may be 64MB, since this is hard coded in google's protocol buffer impl.
> static const int kDefaultTotalBytesLimit = 64 << 20;  // 64MB
By the way, size of block varies, depending on consensus model. In case of noops, the max number of transaction per block is 500.

> consensus/noops/config.yml
> block:
>    # Number of transactions per block. Must be > 0. Set to 1 for testing
>    size: 500
In case of pbft, the default value is "2" in batch mode. I guess this is a kind of trade off of consensus speed and block creation.
<@U1KHPAQ84|nickitastic90> has joined the channel
<@U1KJ36P7X|alexander.yanakiev> has joined the channel
<@U1KJLGH8D|mariwade> has joined the channel
<@U1KJQFPMW|nguyennhatquang> has joined the channel
<@U1KJY9BJQ|skarim> has joined the channel
<@U1KKDE7PX|hutchig> has joined the channel
<@U1KKJ2KC7|goatwizard> has joined the channel
<@U11CP8FF1>   dumb question, but is there a difference with fabric versus sawtooth Lake?  Im just getting started here...
<@U150L8BDF>: stl is python and fabric is go;-) j/k
:flushed:  THANKS!!
<@U150L8BDF>: stl has PoET as its consensus algo… Hyper right now has pbft and noops
noops is no consensus algorithm

I think one major difference is how the two deal with permission. Fabric is primarily designed to handle a permissioned network of peers, where STL supports permissionless. Also, STL has innovated around consensus and created POET (proof of elapsed time) where Fabric is focused on PBFT and a derivative we call Sieve
we also have different approaches for 'smart conteacts'
<@U0XR6J961>: correct… just mentioning...
note that the two are not in competition... this is not a bake off, but we are looking for synergies between top level projects
<@U0KM61BCP>: In case I want to use PoET (which is written in Python) in Hyperledger, does it mean I will have to rewrite it in go using Hyper using Consensus Framework?
Or is there a way I can call consensus algo written in other languages form go?
<@U18D82GJH>: the consensus portion is abstracted to a degree, though the focus has been on alternate golang based impls….im sure with some extra work that could be extended to something external
for instance, I think in many cases, the interface is message based and using protobufs, both of which are conducive to language neutrality
but im sure there would be a few challenges as this was not the design goal
good info.  Im sure if I RTFM its there but this helps.  So are there different block size, transaction limitations?
<@U0KPFAZNF>: got it..thanks.. certainly a message based approach will be useful… Just out of curiosity how does the validating peers on the same network talk to each other in Hyperledger?
grpc over tcp
thanks..

<@U18D82GJH>: hyperledger is the umbrella project, which contains fabric and sawtooth.  PoET is in sawtooth and thus, you can already use "hyperledger" with PoET.  But I think what you mean above is integrating PoET with fabric, not hyperledger.
<@U1KKVTAAG|walid> has joined the channel
<@U0YQQRNU8>: yes… correct.. thanks for pointing out...
<@U1KL6PMSA|andrey> has joined the channel
<@U1KPVJJ3Z|vidal007> has joined the channel
<@U1KQL3QGJ|jasra79> has joined the channel

<@U0KM61BCP>: Just in case you know - are there plans to upgrade this Slack to the paid version? We've already reached the free tier limit (10K messages) and cannot go back to retrieve earlier conversations. This is a problem...
kostas: I looked into it and the pricing is $6.67 per user per month. right now we have something like 1500 users.
<@U0UHG4VP1>: Are you suggesting that's a no?
<@U0XQ35CDD>: the discussion died shortly thereafter. We could approach Slack and ask for an exception, but that is well above my level.

Understood. At any rate, we have a problem in the sense that we're using this tool to exchange valuable technical info that we cannot retrieve after a while. The powers that be can always respond with "deal with it", but I hope that someone understands that this is a problem and is looking into ways to fix. (Whether that means paying for the service, or switching to an alternative, I do not know.)
<@U1KS2KX37|leninmehedy> has joined the channel
<@U1KS2KYF7|marcie> has joined the channel
we should hold most technical discussions via email or in issues and prs
As <@U0UHG4VP1> noted we don't have budget for the number of users
maybe we need find a way to archive the history and move them into some other place which is easy to search.
<https://get.slack.help/hc/en-us/articles/201658943-Exporting-your-team-s-Slack-history>

attachments.title: Exporting your team's Slack history
attachments.text: Team Owners and Admins can export team messages and files from the Export Data page at <http://my.slack.com/services/export|my.slack.com/services/export>. There are two options: Standard Exports and Compliance Exports. See Understandi...

text: <http://slackarchive.io/>
<@U0NCW1DPX>: A lot of LF projects use IRC for stuff like this. The advantage of slack is rich clients and ease of onboarding. The downsides are as kostas noted, and public search, as you noted
IRC is a good choice, but very difficult to connect from China when I was in IBM CDL. not sure if there is any improvement now.
gengjh: looking at today’s TSC notes, I see there is an official IRC channel IRC:  #hyperledger on <http://freenode.net|freenode.net> (has Meetbot)
